facts.text: The respondent was an agriculturist in the district of Agra, assessed to agricultural Income-tax for the year 1358 Fasli.
Income included income derived from direct agricultural operations carried on by the respondent himself.
In the return filed, the respondent showed gross receipt of Rs. 10,899 as proceeds of sale of all agricultural produce and claimed Rs. 5,769-12-3 as expenses of cultivation.
Agricultural income computed under section 6(2)(b) of the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 due to option exercised by respondent.
Assessing authority did not accept figures, held yield from cultivation valued at Rs. 16,421.
Assessing authority allowed 50% margin for expenses, deducting Rs. 8,210-8-0 from gross proceeds.
State Government through Collector of Agra filed revision before Board of Revision, Agricultural Income-tax, U.P., urging error in allowing Rs. 8,210-8-0 instead of claimed Rs. 5,769-12-3.
Revision Board referred question to Allahabad High Court instead of deciding.
High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee-respondent.
State Government appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: An assessee files a return showing his income from and the expenses of cultivation under section 6(2)(b) of the Agricultural Income-tax Act. His returns are rejected and the income is determined to be much higher than what has been shown in the returns. Is it open to the assessing authority in view of the increase in the income to allow a larger amount by way of expenses than what was shown in the returns, or is the statement made in the returns binding on the assessee?

petitioner_arguments.text: In view of rule 13 framed by U.P. Government, assessing authority incompetent to allow expenses other than amounts actually paid by assessee on agricultural operations mentioned in rule; since respondent claimed Rs. 5,769-12-3, no justification to allow excess.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 13 under U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948

court_reasoning.text: Computation under section 6(2)(b); sub-clause (iv) requires assessing authority to allow expenses incurred in previous year in raising crop, making fit for market, transporting to market, including maintenance/hire of implements and cattle; no limitation that expenses must be proved as amounts actually paid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provision contemplates assessing authority must determine expenses incurred in raising crop and operations leading to sale.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 13 lays down principles for ordinarily determining expenses under section 6(2)(b)(iv), but cannot fetter power of assessing authority to arrive at correct figure of expenses incurred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule is guideline, not binding limit.

court_reasoning.text: Expenses claimed based on lower yield per respondent; assessing authority estimated higher produce, so justified in estimating higher expenses for that produce.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessing authority had full justification in estimating allowable expenditure higher than claimed when produce estimated higher.

holdings.text: Assessing authority can allow larger expenses than shown in return when rejecting return and determining higher income, as per section 6(2)(b)(iv); rule 13 does not fetter this power; High Court answer correct.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 (U.P. Act No. III of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs computation of agricultural income; requires allowance of expenses incurred in raising crop etc.; assessing authority determines actual expenses incurred.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 (U.P. Act No. III of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Lays down principles for determining expenses, but does not limit assessing authority's power to estimate correct expenses under section 6(2)(b)(iv).

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Allahabad High Court's answer in favour of the assessee-respondent, confirming that the assessing authority could allow a larger amount for expenses than claimed in the return when estimating higher income, and dismissed the State's appeal.
outcome.relief_granted: None specified beyond upholding lower assessment order

key_quotes.text: Is it open to the assessing authority in view of the increase in the income to allow a larger amount by way of expenses than what was shown in the returns, or is the statement made in the returns binding on the assessee?
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: The core legal question referred to and answered by High Court and Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: What this provision contemplates is that the assessing authority must determine the expenses incurred in raising the crop and on operations leading to its sale.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets section 6(2)(b)(iv) as not limiting to proved actual payments.

key_quotes.text: The assessing authority, in thus estimating the allowable expenditure at a figure higher than the amount claimed by the respondent, had full justification in the circumstances that he had estimated the produce also at a higher figure. The answer returned by the High Court was, therefore, perfectly correct.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Concludes reasoning upholding High Court and dismissing appeal.
